abstract.p: In order to be effective, Christian development practitioners need to have a comprehensive understanding of poverty informed by the concepts and definitions used by the poor themselves. Far too often, this is not the case. Research shows that community level understandings of poverty encompass a gamut of relational, material, cultural, psychological, and spiritual variables that are often overlooked, and that need to be taken into account for more effective holistic, transformational development to take place.

Far too often, this is not the case. Research shows that community level understandings of poverty encompass a gamut of relational, material, cultural, psychological, and spiritual variables that are often overlooked, and that need to be taken into account for more effective holistic, transformational development to take place. definition of poverty perception of poverty poverty rural poverty Keywords Introduction Without a doubt, Christians are called to work with the poor, and to serve the needs of the least advantaged.1 To be truly effective in this work, one must have a comprehensive understanding of poverty that goes beyond material depriva- tion to include both the psychological and spiritual aspects of poverty.2 And, this understanding of poverty needs to be informed by the concepts and definitions used by the poor themselves.3 In practice, however, this is very often not the case. Even with the empha- sis on `holistic' and `transformational development' (Myers, 1999), Christian development practitioners still have `blind spots' when it comes to the content and the sources of the formal and informal theories of poverty that guide their actions. On the one hand, the notion of poverty as material deprivation still dominates, with the psychological and spiritual dimensions given short shrift. On the other, even when the psychological and spiritual dimensions of poverty are incorporated, most often this is done by drawing on academic writings and 131 insights and not from consultation with those with whom the development practitioner is working. This article seeks to shed light on those blind spots and point the way towards how evangelical development workers can use a more comprehensive under- standing of poverty to engage in more effective development work. It does so by quickly reviewing theories and understandings of poverty that have informed Christian development practice, and then by contrasting this frame of reference with the results of community-based research done by 60 Eastern University development worker graduate students in 27 different countries of Asia and Africa in 2006 and 2007. This research asked the people of the `poor' communities themselves to define poverty and its causes, their analysis of the state of relation- ships between the `poor' and `non-poor,' and their perception of vulnerability to external shocks. The results of this research show that the understandings of poverty emanating from the `poor' themselves need to be taken into account in development work, and encompass the gamut of relational, material, cultural, psychological, and spiritual variables. If development workers have a greater appreciation for the knowledge that the poor bring to the table on this subject, the opportunities for more effective holistic, transformational development will increase. Understandings of Poverty Over the last decade, evangelical writings on poverty and development have grown significantly in depth and sophistication. These writings have drawn on both secular and religious analyses, and provide a framework for understanding poverty that guides development practice. The most common understanding of poverty comes from the theory of depriva- tion in which the poor experience a deficit that defines their lives (Myers, 1999). Most of the time, it is an obvious deficit of material goods – lack of adequate nutrition, housing, school uniforms or other necessities of life. A more sophisticat- ed version of this approach to poverty concerns a deficit of knowledge: the poor do not have the knowledge necessary to move themselves out of poverty. And, of course, evangelicals should add that the poor have a lack of spiritual connection to God in their lives (Myers, 1999). In fact, the spiritual dimensions of poverty are only one of several factors and variables that add necessary depth to the material understanding of poverty. Robert Chambers, for example, offers the concept of `poverty as entanglement' in which the poor are caught in a `poverty trap' of material poverty, physical weakness, powerlessness, isolation and vulnerability (Chambers, 1983). John Friedman, on the other hand, proposes that poverty comes from a lack of access to social power in which the household is under the influence of power from four different domains: state power, political power, economic power, and social power (Friedman, 1992). And other secular authors, extending as far back as Oscar Lewis in the 1950s, point to cultural factors as being a major explanatory variable (Harrison and Huntingdon, 2001; Lewis, 1966). From an evangelical perspective, Jayakumar Christian takes these theories fur- ther in his description of `poverty as disempowerment'. Like Chambers and his `poverty trap', Christian sees the poor as trapped in a complex web of systems that keeps them disempowered. He addresses the concepts of physical weakness, inadequate worldviews, the marred identity of the poor, and the poor as vic- tims of the `god-complex' of the non-poor. Christian also brings in the spiritual 132 perspective with a categorization of religious systems and notes that the poor are often deceived, in a variety of ways, by evil principalities and powers in rebellion against the kingdom of God (Christian, 1999). Bryant Myers elaborates on Christian's theory, adding that broken relationships between God and his people, among people, and between people and nature, are the causes of poverty and thus the starting point for transformational development (Myers, 1999).4 To what extent do these analyses by evangelical writers mirror the actual frame- works used by Christians to interpret poverty and engage in action? Two decades ago, Richard Mouw (1989) found five distinctive understandings of the poor by evangelical Christians. •~ The~ poor~ are~ made~ in~ the~ image~ of~ God,~ and~ have~ been~ gifted~ by~ God~ but~ lack~ education, and thus the opportunities, skills, and knowledge to move out of poverty. The role of the development worker is to plug the gap of these deprivations. •~ The~ poor~ are~ people~ in~ rebellion,~ living~ out~ their~ sinful~ nature.~ They~ are~ lazy~ and~ make poor choices, and as a result it is their own fault that they are poor. This behavior pattern becomes enshrined in their culture and keeps the society and community in rebellion against God and, therefore, in poverty. This perspective gives development workers the rationale to pursue spiritual transformation in the development process, focusing on redeeming the sinful nature of the poor. •~ The~ poor~ are~ Christ~ incarnate,~ the~ `least~ of~ these'~ (from~ Matthew~ 25).~ Therefore,~ they need love and compassion, and someone to come alongside them as part of the development process to relieve their suffering. •~ The~ poor~ are~ `lost~ souls'~ who~ will~ have~ a~ better~ future~ in~ eternity.~ The~ imperative~ for development workers here is to preach the gospel to save the poor, with `development' work being secondary. •~ The~ poor~ are~ God's~ `favorites':~ `Blessed~ are~ the~ poor~ for~ theirs~ is~ the~ kingdom~ of~ heaven' (Matthew 5:3). In this viewpoint, poverty is seen as having structural causes. The poor are oppressed by the non-poor in a two-tiered structure, and the role of the development worker is to help the poor nd their voice and to work for justice and empowerment within the sociopolitical system. Evangelical development organizations and practitioners have been formed in settings where their understandings of poverty have been shaped by a combina- tion of the concepts and tendencies listed, although the understanding of poverty as a state of material and resource deprivation continues to predominate. All of these understandings, however, share one important limitation: they have been formed with little consultation with the poor themselves. It is high time that, as with any good development practice, we pay attention to what the poor are say- ing about their own understandings of poverty and its causes, and to how those understandings can, and must, shape development efforts. Overcoming Blind Spots on Poverty through Research A development professional enters the vocation already conditioned from previous life experiences, at times including formal education in the field of development. Through these experiences, the development worker forms biases based on either cultural or individual influences as to what works, what is good, and what is right (Samuel, 1995). Included in this previous conditioning is an understanding of pov- erty. When a development worker finds himself in a situation that conflicts with his previous understanding or training, the development worker may be tempted to `reframe' his current experience with the poor to fit his preconceived assumptions 133 (Chambers, 1997). The caution then for development workers is to examine previ- ous conditioning, life experiences, and assumptions concerning poverty, and to be open to changing those assumptions before being tempted to `reframe' the current experience. One of the dangers with current evangelical praxis in development is that it is guided in great part by an application of the theory of deprivation as a work- ing definition of poverty, whether it be in the material or the spiritual sense. In immediately pinpointing what the poor lack as a starting point for development, the development workers are tempted to believe that they are needed by the poor to `fix' the situation, rather than engaging in a journey with them in which gifts, talents, and skills are shared and learned from mutually in the process of develop- ment (Christian, 1999; Myers, 1999). One of the consequences of this starting point is that it hampers this mutual journey, and the effectiveness of the development endeavor, leading to a lack of consultation with the poor around the nature of poverty itself in its fullest dimensions. As part of its Masters in Organizational Leadership degree program, focused on development practice, Eastern University sought to address this problem by creating a course called `Perspectives on Poverty and Development'. During 2006 and 2007, 60 development workers, 28 women and 32 men, from 27 different countries in Asia and Africa, enrolled in this degree program and carried out field research as part of this course. In almost every case, the development worker was a local national studying poverty in his or her own country of birth.5 Before attending the three-day `Perspectives' course, each development profes- sional was asked to spend 48 hours in a community defined by their organization as `poor'. The participants were asked to stay in the home of a local family while filling out a formal research journal of specific questions to guide the collection of primary research. The purpose of these home visits was to build relationships and trust in order to find out how the poor defined their own life situation, what they saw as the causes of their poverty or life situation, their relationships with the poor or non-poor in the community, and their perceptions of vulnerability to the external influences that affected situations of poverty in their community. The graduate students/development workers brought the results of this research to a three day `residency' as part of this course, and examined their find- ings in the light of the theories of poverty and accompanying models of develop- ment. After this three day session each participant was asked to spend another 48 hours in the same home to facilitate a deeper understanding of the household's as well as the community's situation. The unique and important feature about these surveys and research is that those designated as `poor' were explicitly asked about their perceptions of their own situations. Previous research has often used objective measures of income or assets to categorize people as poor, or has been based on observations of the poor rather than on deep discussions with the subjects of the study. The rest of this article looks at the information that was gathered, focusing on what these professional development workers had not realized about poverty in their own countries before undertaking the Perspectives course and engaging in the field research. Blind spots, prejudices, and many other preconceived understand- ings of the development workers were revealed and challenged. In reviewing the information collected by the development workers, patterns and trends emerged, some that supported previous understandings of the poor, and some that provides added insight for evangelicals working in the field of development. 134 Defining Poverty The first question the development workers in the `Perspectives on Poverty and Development' course presented to the poor was to ask them to define and describe their own situations. This was the key question in this study as most development professionals arrived in a community with a preconceived understanding of pov- erty from their training and life experiences. Many of the researchers found their preconditioned understandings significantly challenged by the results. A textbook understanding of poverty is that the poor are those who cannot `command sufficient resources to satisfy basic needs' (Todaro and Stephen, 2006: 202). The poor may be counted as those living below a specific level of real income, measured in purchasing power parity (PPP), or the `less than a dollar a day' concept used by the World Bank (that amount has been adjusted for infla- tion to $1.25 per day as of 2008). Since the organization for which the graduate students worked focused on the `poorest of the poor' (less than $1.25 per day), the participants in this study chose to visit families who were determined to be `poor' by this `objective' international standard.6 What the development workers came to find out through their research was that poverty meant many different things to different people,7 and that identifying their hosts in the community as `poor' surprised and insulted many of the community members who entered into such discussions with the researchers. In large part, this was because the definition of `poor' used at the community level was based not on level of income received, but rather on the assets that one owned. In Southern Sudan and Ethiopia, for example, as in many regions of East Africa, researchers found that the number of oxen owned was an indicator of wealth and status within the community. If a community member owned even one ox, he was not considered poor. Yet development projects were set up among these people who had no idea they needed `help' from the outside world because they were not poor in their own eyes. In Ethiopia, owning three pairs of oxen determined that one was a very wealthy man, whereas in Southern Sudan it was two. The ownership of plough oxen, dairy cows, and even land provided assets that could generate an income, therefore the owner was not considered poor within the community. However, a development worker from outside of that area might label these rural farmers as the `poorest of the poor' if one used the arbitrary definition from the World Bank, even though these people did not consider themselves poor. One researcher from Tanzania confessed that he had understood poverty as primarily material deprivation, but when he interviewed the community mem- bers whom he determined as `poor' he was surprised that they did not define poverty in the same way. The community members confidently claimed that they were not poor at all, and then listed the `assets' that they owned, the sources of their income, and even their vision for the future. These people, who from an out- sider 's perspective would clearly fit the World Bank definition of the `poorest of the poor', refused to say that that poverty was an issue in their community. In this particular case, the development worker was able to discuss the issue more deeply on his second visit to the community. In his second visit his new friends shared with him that they used to think that poverty was just a question of material wealth, but after the development organization's work in the com- munity, their attitude and understanding had changed to the belief that knowl- edge of the resources available and the motivation to work can prevent one from 135 experiencing poverty. The conclusion of this researcher was that the definition of poverty was derived from one's attitude and perspective rather than material wealth or income. In another part of Africa, a Ugandan development worker reached an identi- cal conclusion after he visited a slum in Kampala, Uganda, and spent time in two different homes with identical material circumstances: both homes were the same size and in the same neighborhood, and both households were headed up by women in their mid-30s.8 In the first home, the researcher was greeted with warm hospitality and invited into a small home that was clean and well-kept. The homeowner also took care of herself, shared what little she had to eat, and claimed that she was not poor at all. The researcher visited the second home, which showed no signs of care, and the woman who headed the second house- hold expressed significant self-pity and claimed to be a victim of her circum- stances. In these contrasting cases, it would be difficult to say that an `objective' definition of poverty could be rooted in issues of income levels or material pos- sessions. Rather, the definitions appear to be based in the perspective and attitude of the specific people involved.9 In summary, throughout these regions of East Africa the development workers found that it was difficult, if not impossible, to predict who would identify them- selves as poor based solely on the level of material possessions. In other words, the psychological variables, the variables of attitude and perspective, rather than variables within the framework of material deprivation, were far more important for explaining how people understood poverty. Some people in these communities who to the outsider appeared to be poor based on the understanding of poverty as material deprivation refused to label themselves as such and appeared to make do with what they had and lead contented, although difficult, lives. Others, at the same level of material wealth, labeled themselves as poor and led less contented lives. What does this mean for development work? People in these communities may have been caught in a `poverty trap' of their physical circumstances as defined by Chambers (1983), but there is no doubt that the implications of this trap had much to do with their own perceptions. The attitudes and perceptions, one could posit, might hold the key to not only a higher quality of life based on what one does have, but also might hold the keys to possibilities for development: those with more hope and more positive outlook might be able to better take advantage of and help create opportunities for progress. Therefore, development workers coming into communities such as these need to reframe their own perceptions and understandings, redefine their rationale for working in such a community, remain- ing sensitive to the perceptions of community members, and be aware of the need to help nurture and foster attitudes and perceptions that lead to hope amidst dif- ficult situations, rather than relying on arbitrary statistics or shallow understand- ings that define poverty in ways that hide these important factor. And, in order to do this, one must be aware of what gives rise to these attitudes and perceptions, in short, what the causes of poverty are as seen by the people themselves. Causes of Poverty In defining poverty, the question of what causes poverty was asked during the conversations that the development workers had with the homes and communi- ties they visited. In these conversations, they realized that their own preconceived notions of the causes of poverty were challenged by the responses they heard. 136 Once again, the researchers found that the causes perceived by the community had little to do with lack of material assets or income, but that the psychological and spiritual causes of poverty were much more influential and important to the subjects of these community visits.1 0 In Vietnam, for example, those who self-identified as poor felt that their mate- rial circumstances were a result of failures in an earlier life, therefore attributing everything wrong in their current life as punishment for wrongs done in the dis- tant past. This left them with a sense of hopelessness, an attitude of `cannot do', and thus with no motivation to try to change their current situation. They were very sensitive to the supernatural influences in their lives, and believed that the spiritual powers left them no control over their material circumstances. Similar explanations were found within communities across East Africa in Christian and non-Christian households. In Ethiopia, for example, some believed that their cur- rent poverty was a result of God's punishment on the past and present genera- tions' sins. In other words, the cause of their poverty, as they identified it, was spiritual, an example of Jayakumar Christian's `deception by principalities and powers' within the religious system of his model of `poverty as disempowerment' (Christian, 1999). Until the spiritual deception could be dealt with in the develop- ment process, the people of these communities had no reason to believe that their levels of living or poor material circumstances could be changed.1 11 The spiritual causes of poverty were supplemented by a variety of other vari- ables identified by people in the communities visited by the researchers. Some blamed their poverty on their families: they were destined to be poor simply because they were `born into poverty', or because their fathers and forefathers did not leave them property to inherit so that they could establish a life for their own families in the current generation. Others believed that the cause of poverty was the deterioration of economic conditions due toward the lack of government efforts to help the poor. Finally, some identified the causes of poverty as a lack of education, and some as laziness, inefficiency, or incompetence by the poor themselves. Those who blamed their families or the government felt little respon- sibility for the situation and little power to change it, a classic case of feelings of disempowerment (Friedman, 1992). Quite a different picture emerged, however, from Kenya, where development workers interviewed community members in the slums of Kibera, Nairobi. There, the development workers found that the causes of poverty were seen as tem- porary by the community members, who claimed that because they were liter- ate, they were able to work, and were just waiting for opportunity for gainful employment so that they could move to a better place. These community mem- bers pointed out that only when one became infected with HIV/AIDS did the causes of poverty become permanent, as one became locked into a web of physi- cal weakness, isolation, vulnerability, and powerlessness, echoing the analysis of the poverty trap described by Chambers (1983). This disease is seen as a cause of poverty at both the micro level of the community as well as the macro pandemic level, bringing with it feelings of hopelessness and helplessness. A final, and major, cause of poverty identified in the research had to do with the state of relationships within the communities themselves. People in the com- munities themselves stated that broken, conflictive, and unjust relationships in and of themselves were major causes of poverty, and it is to the relational aspect that we now turn. 137 Relationships within the Community Many of the development workers found through their interviews that relation- ships within the community were a significant factor determining the material circumstances and provided another challenge to their development work that they had not previously considered. In communities in Tanzania, for example, people in the communities expressed that broken and unjust relationships were the cause of poverty. There were broken relationships between Christians and other religious groups in the community that were independent of material cir- cumstances or levels of income. There were also broken relationships among the poor, where they would not share their surplus crops or care for each other 's children, keeping families isolated and poor. There were also broken relationships among community members and development workers who were trying to bring in support activities and interventions that would help the community have a bet- ter life. These broken relationships, part of the psychological and spiritual aspects of poverty, created an `absence of shalom' as described in Jayakumar Christian's and Bryant Myer 's models of poverty (Christian, 1999; Myers, 1999). In the Philippines, the developments worker found a similar perceived rela- tionship between problems in relationships, attitudes and feelings, and material difficulties, albeit with a different perceptual starting point. A feeling of hope- lessness had led to an attitude of passivity, not caring about others and thus not wanting to participate in the development activities and projects. Community members reported that they `faced the pain of malicious gossip and criticism, the difficulty of relating to different personalities, and the hardship of thinking through and analyzing problems and solutions'. In one community in Cambodia, on the other hand, the development worker found a spirit of caring and cooperation within a community that resulted from the strength of the community leaders. The communities in Cambodia had no more material wealth than the communities in the Philippines as measured by traditional statistics, and even though both fit the category of the `poorest of the poor' using the World Bank criteria, they had very different types of relationships within the community. In this particular community in Cambodia, the leadership showed compassion and concern for the members of the community. They cre- ated a community of transparency and trust so that they could foster activities to help the poor such as community savings, microloans, and income management projects. One development worker commented that a community such as this was rare in Cambodia, but that the strong local leadership could truly change the way a poor community functioned. In the same way, researchers found communities in Ethiopia where a variety of social structures and relationships existed that helped to prevent poverty. Some of these were kinship-based, where living and working in kinship groups helped one avoid poverty as the groups took care of one another and met together to plan their income generating activities. Others were community-based support systems, with a strong focus on support outside of the kinship groups for orphans and vulnerable children and for community members experiencing illness, death of a relative, or other hardships. It is one thing to identify the important impact on poverty and quality of life that particular kinds of relationships, attitudes, systems, and leaders have in a community. It is quite another to apply these insights to development programs, since changing relationships, attitudes, and perceptions is a process fraught with 138 challenges, especially when relationships are broken. In Zimbabwe, the develop- ment workers assumed that offering self-help or support groups in a particular community would provide a common rallying point for the community to come together to effect change. Yet, local level and macro level conflict and disillu- sionment had `crowded out' any sense of support among community members. Conflicts among local leaders overshadowed the development needs of the com- munity. There was a lack of unity and love among the people there, one develop- ment worker summed up her experience there in this way: `I have never seen two men from this area walking side by side'. In fact, lack of unity, power struggles, and infighting are, as people in the com- munities stated, a major cause of poverty and are a serious restraint to the devel- opment process. Many times, these conflicts stem from the relationships between the poor and non-poor and the attitudes and perceptions that accompany them, and for this reason it is important to examine those relationships more closely.1 2 The Relationship of the Poor to the Non-poor The relationship between the poor and non-poor in the communities was a major focal point of the research carried out by the graduate students. The guiding ques- tions were the following: `How do the non-poor of the community describe the poor? What is their individual or collective relationship to them? What was the relationship of the members of their households to the non-poor?' Based on the responses from community members to these questions, the researchers found that the relationships between the poor and the non-poor affected the community members' perceptions of the causes of their material cir- cumstances and of their social status. Many of these preconceived definitions of poverty in the minds of both groups come out of the relationship between them and the way that each group perceived the other. Few researchers found a positive relationship between the poor and the non- poor. One example of a positive relationship was in a community in Ethiopia where the researcher found that the non-poor in the community she visited were willing to share seed and oxen with the poor, and to loan money to the non-poor to get them through challenging times. More often, however, the researchers found either an adversarial relationship or very negative perceptions of the poor by the non-poor. A common trend was that the non-poor of the community saw the poor as `lazy', blaming the poor themselves for their own poor material con- ditions. This attitude was prevalent in communities even where there was little evidence to distinguish the poor from the non-poor. In several countries in Africa, the researchers found that the non-poor were exploiting the poor. One example of this was hiring the children of the poor to herd the animals of the non-poor. This freed up the non-poor children from the family responsibilities so that they could go to school, meanwhile preventing the poor children from receiving an education.13 Exploitive relationships were also found in Cambodia, but rather than consisting of an exploitation of labor, they were based on usury. A common finding across the researchers was that the non-poor usually hired the poor for their own benefit, not for the benefit of providing income for the poor, and that the poor were not given leadership positions in the traditional social structure so that they could make decisions to protect their own welfare and that of their children. One additional key facet to these non-poor/poor relationships was that the non-poor discouraged the poor from aspiring to a better life, perpetuating the belief that the poor were inferior and keeping them in a subservient position. 139 However, this was not necessarily a `conscious' or `intentional' purpose by the non-poor, in that their attitudes and actions towards the poor were legitimated through a variety of beliefs. For example, the belief of the non-poor in several Ethiopian communities was that the poor were actually created by God to `serve' the non-poor. In a community in Swaziland, the poor were described by the non- poor as cursed ones who are too lazy to take care of themselves. Because the poor do not have enough to eat, or a decent house that can survive the rainy season, they become a burden to the non-poor. Yet the non-poor in this community described the poor as people given to them by God to work for the non-poor. The relationship then becomes one of master and servant, rather than human beings of equal value. This hierarchy of status is ingrained in the poor, who describe the non-poor as masters of their community. At times, they keep them at a distance and engage in other subtle forms of resistance.1 4 They feel deeply inferior to the non-poor, which results in a marred identity (Christian, 1999). One researcher in Swaziland told the story of an older woman who lived in isolation and had no relationship with the non-poor as she felt that her shabby house makes her a `laughing stock to the whole community'. The older woman preferred to live by herself rather than become a `nuisance' to the non-poor. These types of relationships disempower the poor and have a negative effect on their identity. It also makes development work, in the sense of transforma- tion, extremely difficult and complicated. As observed by one of the research- ers, changing the attitude of the people is the most important, yet most difficult goal of the development process, and the non-poor need as much transformation as the poor, if not more. Working with the non-poor to change their attitudes requires added awareness, effort, advocacy and prayer. An evangelical desiring to work with the poor must be aware of the complicated relationship between the poor and the non-poor, and how the barriers to transformation of the individual and community may lie within that relationship. This relationship lies within the psychological and spiritual realm rather than being rooted in the differences in material circumstances defined by levels of income or assets, even though those material aspects are extremely important.1 5 Relationships and Political Power The relationships between the poor and non-poor, and their contribution to the causes of poverty, are complicated by at least one additional major factor: the links that the non-poor have to formal political power. In fact, this was a major cause identified by people in Vietnam of the disparity in levels of living between the poor and non-poor There, the difference between the poor and non-poor was directly attributed to the level of political involvement in the Communist Party system.1 6 Most of the non-poor were involved in political or social organizations, and maintained a high ranking in the Party at the communal or village level. They received training in Ho Chi Minh's philosophies and the Communist Party guidelines while rejecting any notion of God. This periodic training gave the non- poor confidence as well as opportunities to move up within the Party structure, even beyond their local community. Membership in the political system gave them knowledge of and access to those living in the more developed urban areas, including access to new income-generating activities for economic well-being. The poor, on the other hand, had none of these opportunities, leaving them vul- nerable to policy decisions of local Party members and government officials, and with a feeling of despair. 140 In many other countries, while this was not the analysis of the poor themselves, the development workers found similar situations in that those they identified as poor had no voice in the social or political systems, and often they were sys- tematically discriminated against by local authorities due to political or ethnic affiliations. This lack of voice kept the poor in a psychological place of hopeless- ness in which they felt they had no power to change their living conditions. This powerlessness in decision-making provided a much more difficult challenge for development workers than issues of income disparity or material deprivation. The lack of participation in decision-making was also compounded by other kinds of variables involving government. In several instances, development workers found that corruption at the local level of government was as preva- lent as at the national level, further complicating the development process and perpetuating a sense of hopelessness. In Zimbabwe, on the other hand, the local government was famous among the poor communities for its false promises of income generating activities. The local representatives of the central government's Agricultural Ministry were very ineffective in that they had no resources to go into communities to be proactive in supporting the poor, but instead justified their own jobs by helping the already established, wealthier farmers. In addi- tion, in Zimbabwe, it was necessary to be `politically correct', belonging to the `right' political party, to benefit from any key services such as food or educational assistance. As a result of all of this, the poor farmers of the communities felt mar- ginalized and `thrown away', without any power to change their current circum- stances, another expression of what Jayakumar Christian identifies as a marred identity of the poor (Christian, 1999). A different situation involving the legacies of a particular type of governmental system was observed in Ethiopia. In that country, researchers encountered many communities that had been adversely affected by the heavy hand of the former socialist government, the Deurg Regime. This regime had nationalized the entire economy, leading to a state monopoly that paralyzed the private sector and left a high unemployment rate and corresponding lack of productivity in the rural and urban areas. Many of the families in the communities visited by the research- ers had a history of poverty that could be traced to the policies of this particular socialist regime, both from a material and psychological perspective. In addition to lack of employment, the Marxist regime's policies had led to an erosion of creativity, innovation and coping mechanisms. An attitude of despair also domi- nated many of these households. Researchers also found, however, communities and governments that were working well. In Sri Lanka, for example, the poor were able to get political rep- resentation, and thus have a voice, through the creation of Community Based Organizations (CBOs). At first, the development organization had tried to work with local government officials, but encountered considerable `political interfer- ence' in the development process. The formation of a network of CBOs, a model that has worked in other countries, run by an Executive Committee and in charge of its own budget, enabled community members to have a voice in their own development, and thus overcame a sense of hopelessness. In Swaziland, on the other hand, the Ministry of Agriculture worked within local communities to prepare for the farming season. The agricultural officers taught local farmers which crops were best for the region under their particu- lar climatic conditions, promoting a change from maize as the rains diminished to the more drought resistant crops of cassava and jugo beans. The Ministry of 141 Agriculture set up a program to help the farmers bring these new crops to market to sell, allowing the local farmers overcome the insecurity of changing from a crop on which they had previously depended. It is clear that the involvement of local officials can either help or hinder the development process. A development worker, therefore, needs to pay attention to the national as well as local government policies affecting the life chances as well as the attitudes of a community. The development worker also needs to be aware of the political and psychological barriers to and opportunities for development embedded in the relationships between the poor and the government entities in the region. In short, the development worker needs to be trained in a comprehen- sive analysis and approach to advocacy in a way that incorporates the material, psychological, and spiritual elements of that kind of work, looking to understand the relationship between the poor, non-poor, and the government entities in order to work best through them, or in spite of them.1 7 Vulnerability to External Shocks An understanding of the definitions and causes of poverty from the perspective of the poor themselves would not be complete without an understanding of the concept of vulnerability and how it feeds into those perspectives.18 In fact, researchers found that the perception of vulnerability to negative influences from outside the community, defined here as `external shocks', played a key role in the psychological and spiritual well-being of community members and their understanding of poverty. These external shocks took many forms, from the macro level of the political and economic systems to the impact of the natu- ral environment. How the communities perceived and reacted to these external shocks dramatically affected their ability to participate effectively in the devel- opment process. In several communities, the Structural Adjustment Programs (SAPs) initiated by the national governments brought about severe economic turmoil, which left communities very vulnerable to economic influences outside of their control. For example, in Tanzania the national government enacted free market reforms in which price controls were removed. Prices rose quickly, especially for construc- tion materials, petroleum products, farm inputs, and food. This created unexpect- ed economic pressure within a community that was just beginning to experience success from its agricultural development projects and left them with a sense of hopelessness about attaining a higher level of living. External shocks also come in the form of nature itself. Loss of a crop in a drought year can lead to both food insecurity as well as economic insecurity in an agricultural region, and the level of preparedness in a community to weather such shocks directly correlates with the level of fear and uncertainty in a poor community. For example, through strong leadership and vision, the Marungu Community in rural Kenya had established a community savings plan to deal with emergencies and external shocks, and had created alternative income gen- erating activities such as soap and brick making so as to be able to buy food when their crops failed. Likewise, in Zimbabwe, researchers visited families who believed that education and good management of farming and livestock activities could prepare them to survive an external shock and even help others. The com- munity had what they called the `chief's store room', which stored surplus grain for the poor. They operated on a concept of an `extended family' that provided material support for the orphans of the community. There was hope rather than 142 vulnerability in that particular community because their positive attitude had led them to take preventive action. Along these lines, the researchers noted as they compared communities across regions that vulnerability to external shocks was directly related to the differences in attitudes about saving and preparing for the future. In communities where there was a concern for the future beyond the present day, preparation was taken to deal with anticipated natural disasters and there were less feelings of vulner- ability. In communities that did not plan looking forward, and which therefore were not prepared to deal with disasters, people felt extremely vulnerable. In a comparison of these communities, the levels of material development were neg- ligible: what distinguished them was their attitude towards the future and their corresponding levels of preparedness and vulnerability to external shocks.1 9 The understanding and feelings of vulnerability were articulated clearly by the people themselves in the communities. In Ethiopia, the poor families visited by the development workers explained in detail the parameters of the vulnerability of their households to external shocks. They analyzed how they existed in a strug- gle for daily survival, and as a result could not put anything away for reserves, surviving on a daily wage for the household of about 7–10 birr (about one US dol- lar), which barely covered their daily consumption. The families feared getting sick with no money to pay for the local clinic, therefore felt highly vulnerable. Without assets to sell, or relatives in the area to assist them, these families lived in fear of the unexpected. Compounding their fear was the awareness that the mac- roeconomic policy implemented by the central government could severely affect their communities without them having any input into these policies. One researcher was able to discuss with the people of the community she visited a variety of external shocks taking place at that time in Ethiopia that are also symp- tomatic in many developing countries. The people of the community listed infla- tionary pressures on prices, recurrent drought that led to land degradation, popu- lation pressure upon the land that further exacerbated the inability of the land to support its people, and disease from outside the community that affected humans, animals, and even crops. All of these added to their feelings of fear, powerlessness, hopelessness, and vulnerability, the tangled web of which presented as great a challenge to the work of development as did the low levels of living and obvious physical aspects of poverty in the poor communities visited for this study. Conclusion As demonstrated, when the people of 60 `poor' communities in Africa and Asia were asked to define poverty and its causes, their answers were surprising and instructive to the development workers/graduate students/researchers who had engaged them in this conversation. At times, those the development workers con- sidered to be poor based on the `objective' measure of income were insulted and did not consider themselves to be such. Rather, they defined poverty in terms of assets owned, knowledge and motivation. In addition, the researchers discovered that people at apparently similar low levels of material welfare differed in terms of whether they defined themselves as poor or not and in terms of their quality of life. Based on their `attitudes', psychological levels in terms of contentment, hope- fulness, fear, and hopelessness varied tremendously and affected the possibilities for development work. The causes of poverty as defined by the `poor' also pointed to the impor- tance of psychological, spiritual, and relational variables in addition to material 143 ones. As seen earlier, the people in the communities pointed to poverty being a punishment for things done in a previous life or for sins past and present, and as being caused by being born into poverty of into families who did not leave them enough inheritance, a lack of education, a deterioration of economic conditions, lack of jobs, HIV/AIDS, laziness, inefficiency, and incompetence, broken relation- ships at the community level among and between the poor and non-poor, and the differentiated levels of access to political power and resources. This multifaceted nature of social analysis by the poor was also evident as the people of the com- munities shared their understandings of vulnerability, what they had or had not done to prepare for external shocks, and the feelings of hope or hopelessness and fear that they felt as a result. From this discussion, it is clear that development workers must be expand their theory of poverty beyond that of deprivation, and learn to take into account the combination of psychological, spiritual, relational, cultural, and material variables that the poor themselves clearly identify as being part and parcel of the defini- tion and causes of poverty. To be most effective, these evangelical development workers need to put aside their own preconceived assumptions of poverty, and reframe their assumptions, plans, and activities through the perceptual lenses of the poor with whom they are working. The training and education of these development workers needs to include much more than just tools of economic development, such as programs and activities for income generation and human capital development. It needs to include the broader theories of development to include the psychological and spiritual issues faced by the poor. Only when this deeper level of effective engagement takes place in the mind of the development professional will holistic and sustainable development happen.
